ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to more proficiently read, write, speak, and listen in Spanish.  I now feel that I have a good handle on complex Spanish grammar and feel more comfortable reading longer passages.  Daily class with required participation means I have advanced greatly in speaking ability since Zoom classes last year.
I learnt how to communicate more sophisticated information in Spanish and how to analyze Spanish-written literature.

I gained greater familiarity and comfort in discussing a variety of topicsincluding technology, literature, art, and social mediain Spanish. I learned how to incorporate grammar structures according to the nuanced meanings that I intended to express. Moreover, this course pushed me to not only memorize new vocabulary words, but also incorporate them in sentences and essays.
Speaking, reading, and writing in Spanish

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Lots of practice
Weaknesses: Every day, lots of days felt really unnecessary, and was hard to stay engaged with full attention. Fridays were off which was nice but this could surely be a 3/week class. Grading was very slow, did not get grades back until several weeks after. Course-wide organization by the course head was not great. The syllabus was very loosely followed.

Strengths - high student engagement, clear instructor feedback, relevant course material
Weaknesses - low classmate engagement, overly complex reading at times

In terms of strengths, the course material and format are highly engaging and interactive. For example, we participated in debates with each other, created podcasts/videos, and spent time free-writing. Professor Glenski is an excellent discussion facilitator, and I improved my grammar while speaking in Spanish because she effectively corrected me when I made mistakes. I cannot identify any weaknesses!
I enjoyed the in-class activities. The only weakness I can think of is that almost all of our major assessments were graded right at the end of the term.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you have to take it

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to anyone fulfilling a language credit or looking to further their understanding of the Spanish language.  The work can certainly pile up, but staying on top of assignments is feasible and makes classroom learning much easier.

Yes. Sarah Glenski is an amazing person, very sweet, kind, and considerate, but the course sometimes felt pretty unorganized and all over the place. She's pretty lenient and understanding though. I would only consider taking the course with another professor if you feel you require someone with a lot of technical understanding of the language or someone who is very thorough and organized in their teaching.
It is great class for students who would like to advance their Spanish skills and I would definitely recommend it.
I would recommend this to anyone who's interested in improving their Spanish!
yes, if they are interested in learning spanish
